title: Changelog
description: Changelogs and improvements to the Documents projects.
content:
## Added

**Linting and Formatting**:

* Added `npm run lint` and `npm run lint:fix` scripts to automate linting tasks.
* Added `npm run format` and `npm run format:check` scripts to ensure consistent code formatting.

**SEO Enhancements**:

* Added an SEO component to MDX pages to dynamically include `keywords` and `lastModified` metadata for improved SEO generation.

## Updated

**Next.js Upgrade**:

* Upgraded the project from **Next.js 14** to **Next.js 15**, leveraging the latest features and performance improvements.

**Codebase Improvements**:

* Reordered imports across the project files for better consistency and readability.

**Mermaid Component**:

* Fixed an ID bug that caused rendering issues when multiple Mermaid diagrams were included in MDX pages.
* Improved initialization and rendering logic to prevent duplicate diagram rendering.

title: Introduction
description: Welcome to your documentation-driven journey into web development! This guide will take you from the very beginning, step-by-step, to building your first web pages. You'll learn essential computer skills, set up your development environment, and master HTML through clear, concise documentation.
content: ![Banner](/images/cadu-computer.gif "Learning Path") ## Your Web Development Blueprint Embark on an exciting journey from complete beginner to confident web developer! This meticulously designed path will empower you to: üöÄ **Launch Your Journey** by mastering essential computer literacy skills, forming a solid foundation for your coding adventure. Feel free to navigate through the course and skim over the content to get a feel for what's ahead. üõ† **Customize Your IDE** by choosing your preferred Integrated Development Environment (we'll be using VS Code) and learning how to navigate documentation effectively, streamlining your workflow. üåê **Build Real Websites** by learning HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and expanding your skills to modern frameworks like React, Next.js, and Tailwind CSS. It's a good idea to skim through the content to get a feel for the topics covered. We've designed this path to give you *actual coding superpowers* through: * **Guided skill progression** from absolute basics to portfolio-worthy projects * **Hands-on browser experiments** that make concepts stick * **Professional workflows** used by industry developers * **Instant feedback** through interactive examples üöÄ **Hit a learning wall?** Don't worry! We've got your back with proven strategies for absorbing technical concepts. Bookmark this section and return anytime you need a productivity boost! *** ## Computer Fundamentals Master essential computer skills for developers - from file management to system navigation and understanding file types keywords: * file system * folders * file extensions * computer basics * developer fundamentals * system navigation *** ## Basic Computer Operations ### Navigating Your OS * Windows/Mac/Linux interface fundamentals * Using mouse vs keyboard navigation * Common keyboard shortcuts: * `Win+E` / `Cmd+Space` (File Explorer/Spotlight) * `Ctrl+C` / `Cmd+C` (Copy) * `Ctrl+V` / `Cmd+V` (Paste) ### Files and Folders Management ```text üìÅ Documents/ ‚îú‚îÄ üìÅ Projects/ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ üìÑ report.txt ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ üìÅ images/ ‚îî‚îÄ üìÅ Downloads/ ‚îî‚îÄ üìÑ setup.exe ``` * Creating/moving/deleting files * Organizational best practices: * Clear naming conventions (`project_v2_final_REAL`) * Logical folder hierarchy * Regular backups Always check file paths before deleting - system files are often hidden! ### File Types and Extensions | Category | Examples | Purpose | |----------|----------------|-----------------------------| | Text | .txt, .md | Unformatted text documents | | Code | .js, .html | Programming source files | | Media | .jpg, .mp4 | Images, videos, audio | | Archives | .zip, .tar | Compressed file bundles | Key concepts: * Extension determines file association (.html opens in browser) * Hidden files (e.g., .gitignore, .env) * Executable warnings (.exe, .sh, .bat) 2. **Development Environment**: Setting up and customizing your IDE (Integrated Development Environment) 3. **First Steps with HTML**: Learn the markup language that structures all web content **Hands-On Approach:** We recommend practicing each concept as you learn. Web development skills are best acquired through active experimentation - don't hesitate to break things and fix them! ## Why Start with HTML? HTML (HyperText Markup Language) forms the backbone of all web content. As a markup language rather than a programming language, it provides an accessible entry point to: * Understand content structure * Learn element hierarchy * Practice semantic organization * Prepare for CSS styling * Transition to dynamic content ## Learning Progression | Stage | Focus Area | Key Skills | | ----- | ------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | 1 | Computer Literacy | File systems, basic terminal commands, software installation | | 2 | Development Setup | IDE configuration, extensions, workflow optimization | | 3 | HTML Fundamentals | Semantic markup, forms, accessibility basics, document structure | ## Join our Community If you have questions about anything related to web development, you're always welcome to ask our community on [GitHub](https://github.com/rubixvi/rubix-documents), [X (Twitter)](https://x.com/rubixstory), [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/rubixstudios) and [Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/RubixStudios/).

title: Setup
description: Setting up and configuring your documentation project
content:
Setting up your new documentation project is straightforward. Most of the essential project settings can be configured within the `settings` folder.

## Settings

This section provides the core settings for your documentation site, such as defining the site's URL, site icon and title.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const url = ""                 // The URL for your documentation site
export const siteicon = ""            // Icon displayed next to the site name in the header
export const sitename = ""            // Title of your documentation site
```

## Google Tags

This section allows you to integrate Google Tag Manager into your documentation project. You can add your GTM code and configure whether it's connected.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const gtm = ""                 // Add your Google Tag Manager code here
export const gtmconnected = true      // Set to true if GTM is connected, otherwise set to false
```

## Search Engine

Configure essential SEO settings to ensure your documentation site is optimized for search engines. This includes meta descriptions, keywords and social media sharing details like images and alt text.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const description = ""         // Description of your documentation site for SEO
export const keywords = ["", ""]      // List of SEO keywords for your documentation site
export const urlimage = ""            // The URL of the image used when sharing on social media)
export const imagealt = ""            // Alt text for shared images, helpful for screen readers
export const twitterhandle = ""       // Your company‚Äôs Twitter handle for social sharing
```

## Footer Branding

The footer settings allow you to customize the company information displayed at the bottom of the site. You can add the company name and the URL that the name will link to.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const companyname = ""         // The company name displayed in the copyright section
export const companylink = ""         // The URL your company name should link to
```

## General Layout

The layout settings control the appearance and functionality of various elements of the documentation site, such as branding, the right sidebar, feedback options, table of contents, and scroll-to-top functionality.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const branding = true          // Set to true to display our branding elements
export const rightsidebar = true      // Set to true to enable the right sidebar with feedback, table of contents and scroll-to-top
export const feedbackedit = true      // Control to enable/disable feedback on GitHub
export const tableofcontent = true    // Control to enable/disable the generated table of contents
export const totopscroll = true       // Control to enable/disable scroll-to-top button
```

## Github Control

If your MDX files are hosted on GitHub, you can configure the project to load documents directly from there. This option can be useful for syncing documentation updates directly with your repository.

```tsx showLineNumbers
export const loadfromgithub = false   // Set to true to load your MDX documents directly from GitHub
```

## Project Structure

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="Navigation" href="/docs/navigation" icon="alignJustify" variant="small" description="Creating your navigation" />
</CardGrid>

title: Science-Backed Learning Strategies
description: Evidence-based techniques to optimize your learning: spaced repetition, active recall, cognitive load theory, and more
content:
## Optimize Your Learning with Neuroscience

### Core Principles

#### 1. Spaced Repetition: The Memory Booster

**Spaced Repetition**:  Imagine your brain as a garden. Instead of watering all the plants at once, you water them at increasing intervals. This helps the knowledge take root and grow stronger over time. Start by revisiting the material after a short time (like 1 hour), then a bit longer (1 day), then even longer (3 days), and so on (1 week). This way, you're not just memorizing, you're truly learning!

#### 2. Visualize Your Learning: The Mind's Eye Technique

**Visualization**: When you're reading or learning something new, try to create a mental movie of it. Just like when you're engrossed in a storybook, picture the concepts in your mind. If you're learning to code, imagine a code editor with someone typing away, or visualize the code on a whiteboard. This makes the learning process more engaging and helps you remember better. Watch a video or two of the topic you're learning about, and then try to picture it in your mind.

3. **Active Recall**: Test yourself instead of re-reading
4. **Interleaving**: Mix different topics in single study sessions
5. **Elaboration**: Connect new concepts to existing knowledge. Think of it like a philosopher, always asking "why?" and "how does this relate?". By linking new information to what you already know, you're building a strong web of understanding, not just isolated facts.

<Note type="tip">
  üß† **Interleaving Tip:** Mixing different subjects during study sessions can boost your brain's ability to connect ideas! Don't be afraid to jump between topics.
</Note>

### Proven Techniques

**The Feynman Technique: Unleash Your Inner Teacher!**
Ever heard of Richard Feynman? He was a super-smart physicist (check him out on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Feynman)!) and this technique is named after him. It's all about making sure you *really* get something, not just memorizing it like a parrot. Here's the fun part:

1. **Become the Teacher:** Imagine you're explaining the concept to your best friend, a curious kid, or even a rubber ducky! If you can't explain it simply, it's a sign you need to dig a little deeper.
2. **Detective Mode:** As you're explaining, pay attention to where you get stuck or confused. Those are the clues that show you what you need to focus on!
3. **Simplify, Simplify!:** Break down the tricky parts into easy-peasy terms. Use analogies and examples to make it super clear.
4. **Rinse and Repeat:** Keep going through the process until you can explain the concept clearly and confidently. You'll be a pro in no time!

This technique is a fantastic way to solidify your understanding and identify areas where you need more work. It's like having your own personal Feynman in your study sessions!

**Pomodoro + Deep Work**

* 25m focused work ‚Üí 5m break (4 cycles)
* 30m review session after breaks

<Note type="tip">
  üß† **Sleep is Secret Sauce:** Studies show sleep consolidates memories.
  Never sacrifice sleep for "one more hour" of studying!
</Note>

### Common Pitfalls to Avoid

| Mistake          | Better Approach               | Neuroscience Basis                 |
|------------------|-------------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Cramming         | Distributed practice          | Enhances long-term potentiation   |
| Passive reading  | Self-testing                   | Engages retrieval pathways        |
| Multitasking     | Single-task focus              | Reduces context switching costs    |
| Overhighlighting | Generate own examples          | Strengthens semantic encoding      |

### Personalized Learning Plan

1. **Diagnose** your learning style (visual/auditory/kinesthetic)
2. **Schedule** 3x weekly sessions (45m each)
3. **Track** progress with spaced repetition app (Anki, Quizlet)
4. **Reflect** weekly on what's working/not

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="Study Schedule Template" subtitle="PDF Download" description="Pre-made timetable using spaced repetition principles" href="/downloads/learning-schedule.pdf" />

  <Card title="Further Reading" subtitle="Research Papers" description="Original studies on cognitive load theory and memory" href="/references/learning-science" />
</CardGrid>

title: Filetree
description: This section provides an overview of file structures and their implementation using the FileTree component.
content:
This section demonstrates the structure of a file tree using the `FileTree` component. Below is an example showcasing folders and files organized hierarchically for a project setup.

<FileTree>
  <Folder name="src" label="Source Code">
    <File name="index.tsx" label="Index File" />

    <Folder name="components" label="Components">
      <File name="button.tsx" label="Button Component" />

      <File name="input.tsx" label="Input Component" />
    </Folder>

    <Folder name="pages" label="Pages">
      <File name="home.tsx" label="Home Page" />

      <File name="about.tsx" label="About Page" />
    </Folder>
  </Folder>
</FileTree>

## How to Use

Integrate the `FileTree` component into your project to visually represent file and folder structures. This is particularly useful for documentation, tutorials, or providing users with an overview of your project's architecture.

### JSX Code Example

Here is how you can define the file tree structure in for use in your project:

```jsx
<FileTree>
  <Folder name="src" label="Source Code">
    <File name="index.tsx" label="Index File" />
    <Folder name="components" label="Components">
      <File name="button.tsx" label="Button Component" />
      <File name="input.tsx" label="Input Component" />
    </Folder>
    <Folder name="pages" label="Pages">
      <File name="home.tsx" label="Home Page" />
      <File name="about.tsx" label="About Page" />
    </Folder>
  </Folder>
</FileTree>
```

Use this code as a template to set up your own file tree structure and customize it as needed.

title: Lists
description: This section provides an overview of creating and using lists in the Documents boilerplate.
content:
Learn how to create and render different types of lists in the Documents boilerplate. Examples include checklists, ordered lists, unordered lists and nested lists.

## Checklist

* \[x] Write the press release
* \[ ] Update the website
* \[ ] Contact the media

```jsx
- [x] Write the press release
- [ ] Update the website
- [ ] Contact the media
```

## Simple List

* Item 1
* Item 2
* Item 3

```jsx
- Item 1
- Item 2
- Item 3
```

## Number List

1. Research
2. Draft the content
3. Review and edit
4. Publish

```jsx
1. Research
2. Draft the content
3. Review and edit
4. Publish
```

## Nested List

* Main Category 1
  * Sub Item 1.1
  * Sub Item 1.2
* Main Category 2
  * Sub Item 2.1
  * Sub Item 2.2

```jsx
- Main Category 1
  - Sub Item 1.1
  - Sub Item 1.2
- Main Category 2
  - Sub Item 2.1
  - Sub Item 2.2
```

Use these examples as a foundation to create and customize lists that fit your project's needs.

title: Maths
description: This section provides an overview of Introduction.
content:
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Numquam iste dolorum tempore consectetur explicabo tempora provident quia maxime, molestiae, facilis aperiam et, error illum vel ullam? Quis architecto dolore ullam

## Basic Algebra

The area of a circle ($$A$$) can be calculated using the radius ($$r$$) as follows:

```math
A = \pi r^2
```

## Quadratic Formula

The quadratic formula for solving an equation of the form $$ax^2 + bx + c = 0$$ is:

```math
x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}
```

## Newton's Second Law of Motion

Newton's second law of motion states that force ($$F$$) is the product of mass ($$m$$) and acceleration ($$a$$):

```math
F = ma
```

## Pythagorean Theorem

The Pythagorean theorem relates the lengths of the sides of a right triangle:

```math
a^2 + b^2 = c^2
```

## Einstein's Mass-Energy Equivalence

Einstein's famous equation relates energy ($$E$$), mass ($$m$$), and the speed of light ($$c$$):

```math
E = mc^2
```

title: Steps
description: This section provides an overview of Introduction.
content:
The `<Step>` and `<StepItem>` components allow you to create structured step-by-step guides in your documentation. These components are particularly useful when you want to break down a process or tutorial into easy-to-follow stages.

## Steps

To create a step-by-step guide in your MDX, you can use the following structure:

<Step>
  <StepItem title="Install Node.js">
    Make sure you have Node.js installed on your machine. You can download it from [here](https://nodejs.org).

    To verify the installation, run the following command:

    ```bash
    node -v
    ```
  </StepItem>

  <StepItem title="Install Dependencies">
    After cloning the repository, navigate to the project directory and install the necessary dependencies:

    ```bash
    npm install
    ```
  </StepItem>

  <StepItem title="Run the Project">
    Start the development server:

    ```bash
    npm run dev
    ```

    You can access the application at:

    ```bash
    http://localhost:3000
    ```
  </StepItem>
</Step>
